pol.name: Sack of Rome
pol.desc: Rome is seiged by the troops of Charles V, putting an abrupt end to the Italian Renaissance.

pol.name: Peace of Augsburg
pol.desc: Charles V ends the war against the Schmalkaldic League and legalizes the practice of Protestantism (specifically Lutheranism) in the Holy Roman Empire.

pol.name: Spanish Armada
pol.desc: The Spanish Armada attempts to mount a naval offensive against Britain, and suffers a decisive defeat as a result.

pol.name: 30 Years' War
pol.desc: An elongated armed conflict between the Catholic church and the various Protestant denominations across Europe.

pol.name: Treaty of Westphalia
pol.desc: Ended the 30 Years' War and provided for religious tolerance of Protestants.

pol.name: English Civil War
pol.desc: England enters a period of civil war, ending with the English Commonwealth under Oliver Cromwell.

pol.name: Rump Parliament
pol.desc: Cromwell forcibly dissolves the Rump Parliament and establishes the English Commonwealth, which lasts until 1660

pol.name: Glorious Revolution
pol.desc: King James II of England, after being suspected of harboring Catholic sympathies, is peacefully replaced with William III of Orange-Nassau.

pol.name: War of Spanish Succession
pol.desc: Various European nations fight over the succession of the Spanish throne. Technically, the Habsburgs have the legal right to the throne, but nobody wants a powerful Habsburg state in the middle of their affairs.

pol.name: Pragmatic Sanction
pol.desc: Charles VI of the Holy Roman Empire issues the Pragmatic Sanction, which gave his entire inheritance to his daughter, Maria Theresa.

pol.name: Treaty of Utrecht
pol.desc: Ended the War of Spanish Succession by splitting the German and Spanish Habsburg empires.

pol.name: Seven Years' War
pol.desc: A war between the major powers of Europe over economical affairs.

pol.name: Diplomatic Revolution
pol.desc: Rearranged German alliances between France and Britain.

pol.name: Treaty of Paris
pol.desc: Ends the Seven Years' War and marks the beginning of Britain's global dominance.

pol.name: Tennis Court Oath
pol.desc: The third estate takes the Tennis Court Oath in a nearby tennis court after being thrown out of the Estates-General. This oath marks the beginning of the French Revolution.

pol.name: Coup of 18 Brumaire
pol.desc: Napoleon Bonaparte overthrows the Directory and takes power as the First Consul to France, ending the French Revolution.

pol.name: Napoleonic Defeat
pol.desc: Napoleon abdicates in the face of total defeat after the Allies sign the Treaty of Chaumont.

pol.name: Congress of Vienna
pol.desc: Congress held in Vienna with the goal of restoring Europe to a state from before the French Revolution.

pol.name: Defeat at Waterloo
pol.desc: Napoleon is defeated at Waterloo after the 100 days, and is exiled to the island of Saint Helena.

pol.name: Peterloo Massacre
pol.desc: The Manchester Patriotic Union organizes a public demonstration to gain support for their liberal agenda. The British military attempts to control the crowd, killing a number of people in the ensuing chaos.

pol.name: Decembrist Revolt
pol.desc: Radical Russian military officiers refuse to swear allegiance to Tsar Nicholas I, and are subsequently crushed by the Tsar.

pol.name: Louis Napoleon
pol.desc: Louis Napoleon takes the French throne as the first President of France.

pol.name: Crimean War
pol.desc: Russia attempts to take land from the Ottoman Empire, and the rest of Europe intervenes, resulting in a devastating loss for Russia.

pol.name: Seven Weeks' War
pol.desc: Otto Von Bismarck provokes a war between Prussia and Austria in the interest of capturing key German territories.

pol.name: Dreyfus Affair
pol.desc: A French military officier is falsely accused of handing off secrets to Germany, and the French government blunders while trying to cover it up.

econ.name: Peasants' Revolt
econ.desc: The German peasantry revolt in light of the percieved support from the Lutheran church.

econ.name: Leviathan
econ.desc: Thomas Hobbes publishes his treatise on the nature of the governed through social contract theory.

econ.name: Two Treatises
econ.desc: John Locke publishes his take on social contract theory.

econ.name: War of Jenkins' Ear
econ.desc: Anglo-Spanish war over economic power in America.

econ.name: Social Contract
econ.desc: Rousseau publishes yet another interpretation of the social contract theory.

econ.name: American Revolution
econ.desc: The Americans decide to revolt against Britain. France supports the Americans, creating heavy economical strain.

econ.name: Wealth of Nations
econ.desc: Adam Smith publishes his works on capitalism and the benefits of a competition-driven economy.

econ.name: Factory Act
econ.desc: The Factory Act is passed, imposing limits upon child labour in factories.

econ.name: Repeal of Corn Laws
econ.desc: The English Corn Laws are repealed in the light of the Irish potato famine.

econ.name: Communist Manifesto
econ.desc: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish the Communist Manifesto, drawing from the works of utopian socialists and capitalists.

cult.name: 95 Theses
cult.desc: Martin Luther posts his 95 Theses against the Catholic Chruch's sale of indulgences on the door of the Wittenburg Castle Church.

cult.name: Diet of Worms
cult.desc: The Holy Roman Empire tells Martin Luther to retract his views or face the consequences.

cult.name: Act of Supremacy
cult.desc: King Henry VIII of England declares himself the sole head of the English Anglican church.

cult.name: On The Revolutions...
cult.desc: Nicolaus Copernicus publishes "On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres", marking the beginning of the Scientific Revolution.

cult.name: Council of Trent
cult.desc: The Catholic Church organizes a council to condemn Protestantism and reform the church structure.

cult.name: Saint Bartholomew's Day Massacre
cult.desc: Extensive bloody conflict in France that resulted in the death of many Huguenot leaders, marking a turning point in the French wars of religion.

cult.name: Edict of Nantes
cult.desc: Established legal religious toleration of Calvanists in France under King Henry IV.

cult.name: Astronomia Nova
cult.desc: Kepler (unhappily) publishes his findings after studying the motions of the heavens.

cult.name: Novum Organum
cult.desc: Francis Bacon publishes "Novum Organum", which outlines his system of empirical observation in the context of science.

cult.name: Galileo Condemned
cult.desc: Galileo is accused of heresy and sentenced to house arrest until his death.

cult.name: Discourse on Method
cult.desc: Rene Descartes publishes his work on the deductive system of thought, advocating for a scientific method formed purely of conjecture and reasoning

cult.name: Edict of Fontainebleau
cult.desc: Revoked the Edict of Nantes and sparked a strong liberal reaction.

cult.name: Principia Mathematica
cult.desc: Newton publishes his work on the laws of physics.

cult.name: Spirit of the Laws
cult.desc: Montesquieu publishes his works detailing a system of balanced government.

cult.name: Encyclopedia
cult.desc: Diderot publishes the Encyclopedia, an attempt at cataloguing all human knowledge in one set of books.

cult.name: Emile
cult.desc: Rousseau publishes "Emiel", a treatise advocating the view of men being superior to women.

cult.name: Crime and Punishment
cult.desc: Beccaria publishes his theories on the effective execution of punishment within the boundaries of morality.

cult.name: Vindication of Rights
cult.desc: Wollstonecraft publishes her theories on the position of women in society being equal to that of men.

cult.name: Education Act
cult.desc: British education is taken out of the hands of the Church.
